subject: Re: [junit] Proper use of TestReult
msgSnippet: ... Right. ... My problem with the 4 tests approach is that if for some reason the public API for the tests change, I have to change n+1 test methods. Whereas
messageBody:
On 14 Sep, Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
> One thing you have to understand is that when a assertion failed, the
> method is exited because an Error is thrown. There is no way to avoid
> this unless you write your own JUnit app. I don't think that it's what
> you want...
>

Right.

> if you have 3 mendatory fields, you write 4 methods. The first 3 test
> that you successfully see when fields are missing and the 4th to see if
> everything's fine when you have your 3 mendatory fields. You have done
> quite the same thing (removing one field after another) but my approach is
> more simple.
>
> Remember: "keep tests simple". The more complicated the test code is, the
> more likely you introduce errors in the test code. The goal of unit
> testing is not to debug your test code :-)
>

My problem with the 4 tests approach is that if for some reason the public API
for the tests change, I have to change n+1 test methods. Whereas if I contain
everything in a single test (as I'm doing now) I only have to change it once
when the public API changes (and yes, it has happened).

> to implement the simpliest tests possible:
>
> - use the setUp() method to create your data object
> - create 4 tests methods (in my example it's 4)
> - remove one single mendatory field at the beginning of each test method
> - call the fail() method to tell JUnit that something wrong happend
>

I'm just trying to concentrate all that in one test because I find
Cut'n'Paste to be error prone. In our case, we test data that has 12 or 14
mandatory fields and 3 or 4 optional. Repeating the exact same code 18 times
screams REFACTORING! And to me a proper refactoring of such identical tests is
to put it all in one method. I'm just looking for a friendly way to show 8
failures if 8 of the test cases fail. So far, the best I've come up with is
to create a string with all the names of the fields that have failed and print
them in the fail() call. But it's not very appealing visually.
